awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: One-Dimensional Correlated and Topological Electronic States in Ultra-Clean Carbon Nanotubes
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical: 
By integrating metals and semiconductors into circuits, humans have learned to control the flow of electrons to process information. Despite enormous successes in this field, there are still unsolved challenges. Existing methods to control electron flow produce imprecise levels of electrical current, and often lead to energy wasted as heat. In this project, the team explores a new way of controlling electric current using a novel method for pumping electrons. The pump is built from a single carbon nanotube that is integrated with a microscopic pattern of wires that controls a time-varying electric field. The pump is predicted to carry an electrical current without dissipation of energy. It is also predicted to be useful as a metrological standard for generating a precise current from a frequency source. Additionally, the system unravels new knowledge about the behavior of interacting electrons which is fundamentally different in such reduced-dimensional systems. The project trains students including under-represented minorities and strengthens the pipeline that feeds the science and engineering workforce. Outreach activities for high-school students from under-represented minorities include an annual science summer camp. 

Technical: 
One dimensional (1D) electronic systems are naturally correlated, in contrast to the Fermi liquids that usually form in higher (two and three) dimensions. While topological order has been studied intensely in 2D and 3D, it has received relatively little attention in 1D where the combination of topology and correlations leads to fascinating possibilities. In the early 80s, Thouless predicted that the same topological invariant as in the quantum Hall effect arises in 1D systems, when the magnetic field is replaced by a time-varying periodic potential. This system, known as an adiabatic charge pump or Thouless pump, has not been realized cleanly in condensed matter, due to problems of single-electron charging and sample disorder. The research team’s preliminary results demonstrate the suitability of their long, suspended, ultra-clean carbon nanotubes (CNTs) for realizing the Thouless pump, and related exotic phenomena. Electrons in a long, ultra-clean CNT form either a Wigner crystal, Luttinger liquid, or a correlated insulator state. Upon application of the periodic potential, the system may then evolve into an integer Thouless pump, a fractional Thouless pump, an artificial Mott insulator or other exotic states. This project focuses on the rich physics that can be found in, and between, these exotic states. To access and control the various phenomena, the team will tune (i) the electron density in the CNT, (ii) the wavelength of the external potential, and (iii) the Coulomb interaction strength (a function of CNT band gap). The specific aims of the project are: 1. Map the parameter space of 1D correlated states in the CNT system without an external periodic potential. 2. Introduce topological order by generating an external periodic potential with surface acoustic waves and a precision flip-chip geometry. 3. Study the interplay of correlations and topological order in 1D.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project was aimed at characterizing ultraclean carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and simultaneously developing surface acoustic wave (SAW) integration of ultraclean materials toward periodic potential modulation and Thouless pumping of electric charges for the first time. Significant progress was made and outcomes were reported in each of these tasks during the life of the award.

Our characterization of ultraclean CNTs revealed the electronic version of a novel optical interference effect (the Sagnac effect) for the first time. Such a quantum interference can probe the electronic structure of valleytronic materials such as CNTs (materials with degenerate valleys). In the case of CNTs, this is the first electronic method to determine chiral index (previous methods were based on optical absorption). More generally, it is a new technique for measuring the asymmetry between forward-moving and backward-moving states in an electronic dispersion relationship.

We developed mastery in the design/fabrication of SAW antennas/receivers and made prototype devices that generate SAWs on black lithium niobate. We used these SAW waves to measure and describe the phenomena of acoustoelectric charge pumping in ultraclean graphene. We extended beyond the work of previous authors by describing the acoustoelectric signal across all carrier concentrations, including the charge neutrality point. We also noted the benefits of charge pumping with h-BN-encapsulated graphene for sensing applications. Demonstrating the classical phenomena of acoustoelectric pumping in an ultraclean material is not only an important step toward the Thouless pump but will also support future SAW-enabled explorations of phenomena in low-dimensional materials such as pumping heat near the Carnot limit and flying qubits for quantum computing. Our work was selected as the cover article in the Journal of Applied Physics.

On the topic of flip-chip assembly of CNT-SAW devices, we improved the control of the air-gap distance in flip-chips. Flip-chip assembly is often needed to build hybrid systems when some process steps are incompatible. For example, one chip can withstand high temperature processing, while another chip must be processed at low temperatures. At the final stage of assembly, the two chips are packaged together (face-to-face), to create the desired hybrid system. Our improved flip-chip design used spacers etched into a silicon wafer whose air-gap was verified by capacitance and by optical interference measurements. Our method and results were reported in a poster at the 2023 APS March Meeting and published in a graduate student PhD thesis.

Finally, the effects of (quasi)periodicity were realized unexpectedly in a different setting than envisioned in the proposal. Toward the end of the project, we reported the first experimental evidence of a vernier-like spectrum of electron energy levels in a material. The experimental measurements were enabled by using long, ultraclean CNT quantum dots. The intriguing vernier spectrum was predicted to occur in systems with valley degeneracy, and a left-right asymmetry in the valley. Vernier spectra are useful in this context because a control voltage can be used to prepare an electron in a quantum state with continuous control between a pure valley state vs. a mixed valley state. This work advances the field of valleytronics and provides a useful concept for quantum information processing.

In terms of broader impacts of the project, two graduate and two undergraduate student researchers were trained in the scientific discipline of the project. One of the graduate students joined the industrial workforce. The results were disseminated to society via three publications and several seminars in universities and conferences. This work was also the focus of a feature article in the magazine Physics Today.
